image.altText: The outside of a court building in a CBD.

props.synopsis: Three lawyers will face Australian legal regulators, with one ordered to pay $10,000 in costs, after submitting a legal document prepared with artificial intelligence and found to contain "inaccurate and misleading references".

title.children: Lawyers to face regulators after AI was used for court document

image.altText: A police vehicle at night

props.synopsis: Police are looking for a man who escaped custody in a medical gown and handcuffs in Adelaide's western suburbs, and are warning the public not to approach him.

title.children: Manhunt underway in Adelaide for man in cuffs and hospital gown

image.altText: A woman in black-rimmed glasses against a blue backdrop

props.synopsis: Parents at a South Australian school say they have been left in the dark about photos taken by a principal during a school camp.

title.children: Children interviewed about ex-principal's school camp photos

image.altText: A drone shot of Whyalla, South Australia.

props.synopsis: South Australian police say a woman has died after a dog attack at Whyalla in South Australia's upper Spencer Gulf region this afternoon.

title.children: Woman dies after dog attack in regional South Australia

image.altText: A man wearing a suit looks on.

props.synopsis: The trilateral agreement has come under significant scrutiny, but Australia's top diplomat in London says he believes its future is assured.

title.children: AUKUS will survive Trump, says former defence minister Smith

image.altText: A fence out the front of a prison that says Yatala Labour Prison.

props.synopsis: In sentencing, the South Australian District Court judge said Paul Andrew Robinson's offending was motivated by an "ultimate aim to make a lot of money".

title.children: Correctional services executive jailed over $300k prison rort

image.altText: A young girl at school.

props.synopsis: A girl who was allegedly criminally neglected at the hands of her mother before she died told a friend she was "treated like a slave" and was "scared to go back home", a court has heard.

title.children: Alleged manslaughter victim told classmate she was 'treated like a slave', court hears

image.altText: A man in blue shirt in front of a new headstone and a red flower wreath next to older graves

props.synopsis: South Australian high school students have helped to uncover the legacies of five war veterans who were laid to rest in unmarked graves.

title.children: Students help uncover forgotten stories of WWI veterans and nurses

image.altText: A man wearing a blue shirt and bandana standing next to his yellow Vespa scooter.

props.synopsis: One man, one little yellow Vespa and a 12,000-kilometre road trip to attend every Ashes Test.

title.children: Cricket fanatic crisscrossing Australia on Vespa to attend every Ashes Test

image.altText: Little boy, little girl and their mum hug with Christmas tree in background

props.synopsis: When seven-month-old Evelyn was diagnosed with a rare cancer, her mother was told proton beam therapy would be her daughter's best chance for survival. But the treatment was not available in Australia and still is not three years later.

title.children: Parents, cancer patients say lack of proton therapy 'an embarrassment'

image.altText: A fire truck roof in the foreground with fires around at night

props.synopsis: An 18-year-old who had been a cadet captain in the Country Fire Service admits deliberately lighting a bushfire near Naracoorte, but mental health conditions lower the sentence he might otherwise have been given.

title.children: Volunteer firefighter sentenced for intentionally starting SA bushfire

image.altText: Brendan Doggett jumps as the stumps of Ben Stokes are hit by a ball. Stokes has his back turned.

props.synopsis: Joe Root overcomes a horror mix-up to notch a long-awaited first Test century in Australia, while Australia's seamers largely struggle without the dropped Nathan Lyon. Here are the quick hits from the first day of the pink-ball Ashes Test in Brisbane.

title.children: Five quick hits: Starc shines again as horror run out leaves Stokes fuming

image.altText: A public health official at a parliamentary inquiry.

props.synopsis: South Australia's public health chief says there is a need for more data analysis to determine whether there has been an increase in respiratory illness linked to the state's algal bloom.

title.children: Algal inquiry quizzes health chief about respiratory illness

image.altText: Tim Wilson speaks in parliament house.

props.synopsis: The Liberals argue Labor's industrial relations concessions to the unions are a "handbrake on productivity" but this area has been tricky for the Coalition since John Howard's disastrous overreach.

title.children: Industrial relations should be Coalition's core business but it's risky

image.altText: ADHD thumbnail

props.synopsis: International Day of People with Disability scholar Mark du Potiers shares how attention deficit hyperactivity disorder impacts him day-to-day and what he does to make life more manageable.

title.children: Living with ADHD and how I make my life easier

image.altText: US defense secretary pete hegseth smirks at the camera

props.synopsis: The 84-page report finds US Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth violated policy and could have put American troops at risk when he used the Signal app to discuss military strikes in Yemen.

title.children: Pentagon watchdog releases report on Hegseth's use of Signal app

image.altText: A woman smiling

props.synopsis: A UK public inquiry has concluded that Russian President Vladimir Putin "must have" ordered the Novichok nerve agent attack on Russian double agent Sergei Skripal in 2018.

title.children: Putin bears 'moral responsibility' for 2018 poisoning of UK woman, inquiry finds

image.altText: Yasser Abu Shabab wears a combat vest and holds a rifle as he sits and poses for a picture.

props.synopsis: Gaza militia leader Yasser Abu Shabab, whose anti-Hamas group had been supported by Israel, has been killed after an attack in southern Gaza.

title.children: Israel-aligned anti-Hamas militia leader Yasser Abu Shabab killed

image.altText: A person in a hoodie carries an item around the corner of a building.

props.synopsis: The arrest marks the first time investigators have settled on a suspect in an act that had long vexed law enforcement and spawned a multitude of conspiracy theories.

title.children: FBI arrests suspect over pipe bombs planted on eve of 2021 US Capitol riot

image.altText: A black and white photo of two men pouring alcohol down a drain.

props.synopsis: Prohibition was officially repealed on December 5, 1933. But the beginning of its end can be traced back years earlier — to a highly-publicised massacre by firing squad.

title.children: Bootleggers, gangsters and a massacre: Why America's Prohibition backfired

image.altText: A raccoon is seen passed out on a bathroom floor, in between a black bin and a white toilet.

props.synopsis: Think you have had your ears to the ground? It's time to test your knowledge of the week that was.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Blacked-out raccoon, poor strategy call and the PM's wedding

image.altText: Owen Cooper leans back in a chair and smirks while acting in Adolescence.

props.synopsis: From a send-up of Hollywood studios to a chilling depiction of violence and masculinity to an age-appropriate reality TV romance, these are our favourite TV shows of 2025.

title.children: The Studio to The Golden Bachelor: Our favourite new TV shows in 2025

image.altText: Tasmania AFL licence press conference

props.synopsis: When it comes to the Macquarie Point stadium in Tasmania, there is clearly something deeper at play than seats, concrete and a roof. You simply couldn't vote for it otherwise, writes Chris Rowbottom.

title.children: Those of faith build a cathedral. Footy-mad Tasmanians build a stadium

image.altText: A cylandrical military device on sandy ground

props.synopsis: The Australian Defence Force's bomb disposal squad responds to about 500 unexploded ordnance incidents a year, with many of the devices washing up on beaches.

title.children: Hundreds of unexploded bombs are found every year. Here's what to do if you see one

image.altText: Men in uniiform hand lifejackets to other men on a boat moored on orange sand.

props.synopsis: A group of six Chinese nationals are detained by authorities after two of their group were found in WA's remote Kalumburu community by an off-duty police officer.

title.children: Chinese nationals discovered in remote WA as ABF launch investigation

image.altText: A graphic of a houses under a dollar sign

props.synopsis: Thousands more properties have fallen under Queensland's land tax regime, as the state is projected to raise hundreds of millions in extra revenue each year from the charge.

title.children: Thousands more Queensland properties subject to land tax as net widens

image.altText: Two conjoined PNG twins wearing yellow beanies lie in a small hospital crib.

props.synopsis: A rare set of conjoined twins are being urgently airlifted from Papua New Guinea to Australia, with doctors recommending they be separated as soon as possible.

title.children: Conjoined twins airlifted to Australia as case reaches 'critical' point

image.altText: People at beach

props.synopsis: Just days into summer and a broad heatwave is already spreading across the country.

title.children: Broad heatwave spreads across the state, hottest summer on the cards

image.altText: Aerial photo of traffic at a standstill on a motorway, with trees either side.

props.synopsis: The issue with the commonly used substance caused delays where some motorists were gridlocked for more than 4 hours on Thursday morning.

title.children: What is shotcrete, the material that caused Sydney's M4 tunnel closure?

image.altText: Two men shake hands in front of an airplane on the tarmac of an airport

props.synopsis: The Russian leader's first state visit to India in nearly four years is expected to focus heavily on trade amid a backdrop of international sanctions and Donald Trump's tariff policy.

title.children: What does Vladimir Putin want from India?

image.altText: A male teacher standing in a science classroom speaking to five male students in front of a white board.

props.synopsis: Nationally, there is a teacher shortage and one of the measures used to fill the gap is using undergraduates, but that too can have long-lasting impacts.

title.children: Why high school teachers are getting younger and younger

image.altText: A drone shot of an island

props.synopsis: Little St James is commonly referred to "Epstein Island" and according to attorneys for his accusers, the island was the site of many crimes committed against underage girls.

title.children: Locals called it 'Paedophile Island' but for Epstein it was 'perfect'

image.altText: Indigenous Tribe NYT Lawsuit

props.synopsis: The US publication has filed a lawsuit over a new policy requiring journalists to sign a pledge to refrain from reporting information not authorised for release by the Pentagon.

title.children: New York Times sues the Pentagon over press access restrictions

image.altText: Brodie wearing a netball shirt and holding a netball

props.synopsis: Brodie Taylor has changed the game of netball by overturning disability preconceptions to become the first person in a wheelchair to attain national netball umpiring accreditation.

title.children: This 18-year-old is the first badged netball umpire in a wheelchair
